name: Please, Don’t Touch Anything
description: A brain-racking game about bathroom breaks, screwdrivers and nuclear explosions.
minimum_requirements: OS: Microsoft® Windows® XP / Vista / 7 / 8 Processor: Any processor with at least 1.0GHz Memory: 512 MB RAM Graphics: Any card with at least 128MB Storage: 50 MB available space

reviews.review_text: TLDR: I got this game at 50%, and still feel like it wasn't worth it.   The Good

Things have changed since the review: on release, everything had a single puzzle (except the green buttons). The larger update did change that, which is good. I still don't like the game, but I absolutely concede that the developer made the game more expansive.   HOWEVER, from my original review, I still have issue with the fact the game has no world building. There is no narrative consistency to the endings. They reveal nothing about anything about the world and almost all result in the city being destroyed in a variety of comepletely unrelated ways.  The puzzles themselves are fine, but not exactly that difficult. Since the release of the update there are now quite a few puzzles. I know it's only $5, but I can't really recommend the game to a general audience, nor would I recommend it to people who are making the connection to Papers Please. I made that connection, but it's wrong. If you like puzzles with easyish answers, then yeah this could be your thing.  Caveat: Do you like logic puzzles and clue hunting? Yeah it's probably okay. But still, let me stress the lack of any kind of world-building. It's like sudoku.
They told me not to touch anything.  I touched everything.   11/10

The title is already explained whole idea about this game. Just 'Please, Don’t Touch Anything.'  There are a total of 25 endings in this point & click game. All endings can be obtained by solving puzzles that had been packed in carefully by the developer. Epicly fun adventure to fiddle with.  PS: Don't tell my friend that I did touch something in this game.

This is a great little puzzle game. If you're bored and need something for your brain to do for a bit, this is what you're looking for. Anybody who says that the puzzles are random is either lying or not taking the time to think through the hints staring you in the face the whole game. Really not a bad game for the price.

I was heavily and pleasantly surprised with this game. I can't say for sure what I was expecting, but, well, it wasn't that.  Which is a good thing! The element of surprise works wonderfully with the game, that always creates new and interesting things to do in the room you're in. I really liked how all the elements of the interface in the game are utilized - you have to pay attention to the smallest clues and details, and this investigation was very rewarding.  The puzzles are very interesting and challenging, and I loved the meta-like style - using paper, taking notes, making calculations and logic deductions, the game has kept me engaged throughout with a diverse set of actions. It was challenging and ultimately, a excellent experience.  I think the only problem I have is that there could've been... more. Not in content or in lenght, but some semblance of narrative or a bigger theme, which some similar games have. As it is, the game is more like a puzzle box, a way to explore a single environment. It's great at that, mind you, but there could be more to make the experience more fullfiling and memorable.  Still, extremely recommended, even more so if you can grab it on sale.

I went into this game not expecting much, and I didn't get much. It's a single screen puzzle game that is too difficult and not fun enough.  The game requires a walkthrough - it would take hours to figure out each puzzle, code, and encryption for the game. Each 'playthrough' lasts at maximum, 5 minutes, and then you click reset to try again. Watch some gameplay and you've seen the whole game. It is at maximum a 3 hour experience, however, the game doesn't pretend it is triple-A which I respect.  Unlike similar games, there is no challenge, no story, no progression, nothing. It really, truly, is a short toy. And it accomplishly that decently, at best.  You may be told 'Oh, it's cheap', but I'm not looking at price. It just wasn't all that fun. Kongregate honestly is a better use of time, for free.  Read a walkthrough of the game and you'll see what I mean. Clicking a button 275 times exactly isn't very fun. Clicking a button, then 33221323 or whatever isn't much fun either. The puzzles aren't rewarding and are not intuitive.

Still, got this on sale for 2.50 and it's worth every penny, and if you like this, go buy Papers, please because it's just as oddly engaging. Got this on steam sale for $2.50 and was worth that price for the entertainment for this evening, but I'd struggle justifying a ton more than that.   All in all if you like trial and error setups / brain teasers then you'll like this. Dont get me wrong its not all just pushing random buttons until you find a combination that works because at the end of the day all the hints and clues are there, Some more obvious than others and some are more prone to accidentally entering the correct sequence without actually knowing where the sequence or hint actually came from.   After tinkering with it for about an hour and a half I was able to navagate and locate most of the pieces you would use and was able to achieve most endings (all but about 6-7) of which I opted to look up the solutions online and was plesently surprised that atleast half of those I was on the right track to and probably would've gotten it had I stuck with it, but my frustration levels peaked. To be honest some of the most annoying parts of the game wasn't just solving the clues or finding how to unlock the controls but rather figuring out which control should be used to enter what clue. Sometimes I would spend a great deal of time trying to figure out how to force a code I solved in the clues into a control only to later find that it was supposed to be entered in a differ control.   Ultimately the only hints I will give you to help ease your frustration is to try and pay attention to when you start inputing a sequence into a set of buttons. They almost always show a number of blanks/used key strokes on the monitor. If you have a 4 key number/sequence and you see 6 spots for entry when you start entering, then just skip that sequence as it goes somewhere else. And take note of everything, hints are nicely crafted into just about everything, so if it seems like something it trying to tell you something then it probably is.  8/10 its a good time killer but ultimately once you solve the problems then its essentially unplayable for you, and while I suppose you could take days/months to solve the couple more difficult puzzles if you wanted to do them without help/walkthroughs, Well I just can't see that being continued fun beyond the first few hours since you'd litterally spend days just repeating the same old cycles trying to figure out what you're missing. For me, spending 2 hours or so solving most the puzzles on my own and then going over the harder solutions with a walkthrough was satisfying enough for my needs. I'll probably just let my friends tinker with this game now to see how well they do, other than that its probably going to be uninstalled =P

Please Don’t Touch Anything is a small indie game where you’re filling in for a friend that has to go to the bathroom. It’s not clear what your friend’s tasks are, but his workspace contains a giant metal panel with a single red button and a monitor displaying a view of an anonymous city. His only instruction for you is to not touch anything until he returns. But that big red button is really hard to resist!  There are 25 different endings to Please Don’t Touch Anything, most of which do not do the city any good. It takes only a few steps to reach any of them. The first endings are quite easy to reach. You basically try stuff and see what happens (for examples, new buttons appear on the metal panel). But other endings are much more complex, requiring you to analyse small clues hidden within the scene.   I found half the endings before feeling helpless. Reading a walkthrough, there were maybe 3 additional endings that I could have figured out eventually, with more dedication. Although I understand the remaining ones, most are fairly gratuitous and it’s hard to imagine how players could stumble upon them on their own.  Graphics are entirely made of pixel art. A quick glance at the screenshots will confirm they’re functional but unspectacular. The soundtrack, on the other hand, is a perfect match for the game. It’s chiptune from start to finish, responds to your actions and instils a certain tension, giving the stakes an importance the gameplay alone wouldn’t allow.   Overall, Please Don’t Touch Anything is a decent curiosity that can entertain for a couple of hours, but it’s not an especially clever or polished design. I wouldn’t recommend it especially warmly but there are worse ways to spend 5 bucks and the best part of an evening.  Rating: decent

This is one of those games that you will kinda already know if you are going to like it based on the premise/title alone. Do you like pushing buttons? Do you like avoiding explicit instructions? Do you find randomly clicking buttons with little to no feedback an appealing concept? Because that is literally the entire game. I will say that I had a really hard time solving some of the puzzles (and some I stumbled upon by accident), but those that I genuinely solved without help gave me that good feeling you get from a challenging video game puzzle. Unfortunately, those that I needed some outside help to solve just made me feel bad. I don't want to call it a failure of the game that the puzzles were too hard for me (that's MY failure), but it would have been nice to have a hint or feedback system of some sort just to give a better idea of how to get to the various endings BESIDES the cryptic clues spread around the room. That said, all the clues ARE there, I saw them all at one point or another, I just didn't know how to read them.  The game is funny, and a good diversion for an hour or so. It's not long, but it's fairly priced for that, and really, you know what you're getting into when you buy it. Get ready to click.

I had fun solving puzzles and finding a bunch of endings for about an hour. Some of the puzzles are very logical and you're clued into the solutions in clever ways, and you find different endings by solving some of the puzzles in specific ways. You spend the entire game in front of a single desk that changes depending on which puzzles you solve in what order, and it uses music and sound effects really well. It just feels cool, right when you start playing.  But getting all the endings and solving some of the puzzles get in the way of each other in some pretty frustrating ways. Plenty of the puzzles have less logical solutions, and require that you repeat the same series of actions before you attempt to solve them. Restarting the game to make another attempt is quick, but actually figuring out how to get a lot of the endings stops being fun and starts being tedious. It's something like pixel hunting, but it isn't an issue of graphical limitations, as the game looks very nice. The issue is that you're hunting for clues that you only get from following a specific sequence of events, and to actually use them to solve a puzzle, you need to reset the game and solve a series of puzzles that gets progressively longer as you try to unlock later endings.  One ending, for instance, requires that you find one way to beat the game, make note of some symbols before the game closes itself, reboot the game, complete a specific series of tasks that you can easily lock yourself out of if you haven't trial-and-errored your way into finding the specific puzzle that this clue solves, and then input the symbols. This is not the only puzzle you solve like this, but it is one of the simpler ones in this vein. Two of the endings are unlocked through the exact same series of puzzles, but since you can only get one at a time, you need to do it twice. PDTA is an incredibly repetitive experience and, after a pretty short time, stops hiding clues that make logical sense in clever places and starts being totally impenetrable.  It's just disappointing for a game to leave a really great first impression and then to just totally fall flat.
